text:
The sooner you can start blogging, social and other organic forms of getting your message out there, the better. (And like everyone else said, it’s fine if there’s no search intent or volume for your product. Go after broader, related terms for now.) You aren’t going to see immediate returns, but it takes a long time to build a brand, and you need to start laying that foundation.

Also, don’t give up after a few weeks with no results. If you have a unique perspective, speak the language of your customers, consistently post and properly optimize your content, you *will* eventually gain traction!

I’m currently on this same journey and would be happy to talk more about it. Just DM me anytime.

text: Hi all :raised_hands: I don't know whether it's been discussed here previously, but... how do you build a scalable link-building strategy?? My current strategy involves writing guest posts & adding 2-4 more links from our partners so that I also receive 2-4 links back after the post goes live. The question is basically: how do you find more partners for link exchanges (triangular) & guest posting? Are there any specific tricks you use to find emails/make sure you don't forget to follow-up/automate the process/etc.? Of course, I speak only of quality sites.

elements.text: Hi all

I don't know whether it's been discussed here previously, but... how do you build a scalable link-building strategy?? My current strategy involves writing guest posts & adding 2-4 more links from our partners so that I also receive 2-4 links back after the post goes live. The question is basically: how do you find more partners for link exchanges (triangular) & guest posting? Are there any specific tricks you use to find emails/make sure you don't forget to follow-up/automate the process/etc.? Of course, I speak only of quality sites.

text:
I'd flip this on its head and change the question to “how do I collaborate with more people and get more organic backlinks?”

My backlink strategy is to 
1. Share my content in places I will get links to it en masse. I'm talking content distribution 101. It's going in forums, I'm writing a guest post specially for that piece of content, I'm talking about it on podcasts, I'm sharing it in Slack communities, etc. 
2. Collaborate with the right people at the right places. <@U01JGE01ZA8> is producing some :fire: stuff on this topic at the moment- maybe he can drop in a cool resource? I just interviewed the Webex General Manager. Sure I got a link but the benefit of the collaboration went way deeper.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/DomKent|@DomKent>: Backlink building is dull and and an inefficient use of my time :skull_and_crossbones: 

Do this instead:

:white_check_mark: Make your content more comprehensive 

:white_check_mark: Share it in more and better communities

:white_check_mark: Collaborate with people (not websites)

:white_check_mark: People link to great content when they see it

text:
:sunny: *2022 PLANNING* :sunny:  Hi all - I’ll soon be planning and getting prepped for 2022. What’re you best tips, tools and templates when preparing and planning (for the new year, new quarter, new month)? What things should I be thinking about? What should the output look like (if any) of planning? What’s the most practical way to plan? All with a view to getting the most out of our marketing activity/driving revenue.

My personal context: I’m currently a one-woman marketing team in B2B SaaS. I’m focused on inbound activities but will also have ownership over MQLs in 2022. Our audience is generally lawyers in businesses and our current channels are LinkedIn (may invest some more time on other platforms next year), website/blog, ebooks, about to launch a podcast, starting to do webinars….

All advice and tips appreciated! Thanks in advance :pray:

All with a view to getting the most out of our marketing activity/driving revenue.

My personal context: I’m currently a one-woman marketing team in B2B SaaS. I’m focused on inbound activities but will also have ownership over MQLs in 2022. Our audience is generally lawyers in businesses and our current channels are LinkedIn (may invest some more time on other platforms next year), website/blog, ebooks, about to launch a podcast, starting to do webinars….

All advice and tips appreciated! Thanks in advance

text: I usually start with a few big buckets corresponding with my major goals. So, for example: SEO-driven content (to increase organic traffic), product/solution content (to drive platform signups), news (to increase brand awareness), etc. Then I break each bucket down by our key topics, and then start researching and individual content ideas for each topic. It can be very overwhelming but this approach helps simplify the process as much as possible!

elements.text: I usually start with a few big buckets corresponding with my major goals. So, for example: SEO-driven content (to increase organic traffic), product/solution content (to drive platform signups), news (to increase brand awareness), etc. Then I break each bucket down by our key topics, and then start researching and individual content ideas for each topic. It can be very overwhelming but this approach helps simplify the process as much as possible!

text: Great points! It's been difficult as we have pretty much just been tasked with "make the content department successful" without any tangible business goals. We have been working on SEO with our small team for 2 years but have continued to see organic traffic drop. Which makes sense to me as we are a small team with almost no extra resources. So, since the CEO and CFO have not seen "traffic 10-30x" in the last few years they don't want to invest in SEO anymore - when really at this point the investment has just been our small team of 3. They hired an SEO agency in 2018 but got burnt and don't trust hiring any sort of outside SEO consultants now - even though that's what the team needs. So my idea is to pivot to something like our email list or another place we can show more "immediate" wins as that's what they seem to see as success vs. anything that is more long-term...hoping that makes a bit more sense!

text:
• You can use HARO (<https://www.helpareporter.com/>) to pitch quotes for journalists.
• Guest posts on third-party/partner sites
• Directories sometimes offer do-follow links
• Reddit/Hacker News (if it makes sense for your content) can be good
Another thing you can do is write content intended to attract backlinks (as Dom suggested). I like things that mention clients, partners, and tangentially related sites.

text: I usually start by planning larger content projects or pillar content  aligned with key topics/themes and break it down by quarter, month and content type. Then I'd get more granular and plan blog and social based on the pillar content. If helpful, this is a template I made that I use for planning/sharing with stakeholders: <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Qk3AYq8IyW8cxFrGYg4frkbKnqnvhfjyHq83QGdLnxI/edit#gid=0>

text: Thank you for all your suggestions! I think ToF content on related topics may be the best path. I've kind of shied away from broad ToF content lately because, in the past, I've struggled to prove its ROI. Maybe it's just my experience, but it seems so much easier to communicate the value/success of BoF pieces.

text:
<@U02NXFRKQNP> it is easier to communicate the value of BOFU, in my experience.

How I often communicate up the ladder, is that a buyer journey can take weeks, months or years. The earlier we can get into the consideration set, the greater the chances of closing a deal.

I am working with a client now that faces almost exactly the same issues/challenges. If interested - always happy to hop on a call and brainstorm.
